title-group.article-title: Liglaurates A-E, cytotoxic bis(lauric acid-12yl)lignanoates from the rhizomes of Drynaria roosii Nakaike

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Liglaurates A–E, cytotoxic bis(lauric acid-12yl)lignanoates from the rhizomes of Drynaria roosii Nakaike
Halidan Wufuer a, b, c, 1 , Yanchao Xu a, c, 1 , Dan Wu a, b , Wenwen He a, b , Dongyang Wang a, b ,
Weiming Zhu a, d, ** , Liping Wang a, b, c, *
a State Key Laboratory of Functions and Applications of Medicinal Plants, Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, 550014, China
b The Key Laboratory of Chemistry for Natural Products of Guizhou Province and Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guiyang, 550014, China
c School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, 550025, China
d Laboratory for Marine Drugs and Bioproducts, Pilot National Laboratory for Marine Science and Technology (Qingdao), Qingdao, 266003, China
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Lignan
12-Hydroxyllaurate
HeLa cell Line
Cytotoxic activity

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: A B S T R A C T

Five undescribed bis(lauric acid-12-yl)lignanoates, liglaurates A–E, along with the known methyl and glyceryl 12-caffeoyloxylaurates were isolated from the rhizomes of Drynaria roosii Nakaike. Their structures including absolute configurations were determined by HRESIMS, NMR techniques, and ECD calculation. Liglaurates A–D were isolated as the racemates, among which (±)-liglaurate A and (±)-liglaurate B were synthesized by a metal-mediated oxidative coupling reaction and further resolved as the enantiomerically pure compounds. Liglaurates (+)-A, ()-A, (+)-B, ()-B, (±)-C and (±)-D exhibited remarkable cytotoxic activities against HeLa cell line, with the IC 50 values of 0.11 ± 0.02, 0.24 ± 0.01, 0.02 ± 0.00, 0.13 ± 0.02, 0.34 ± 0.07 and 0.17 ± 0.01 μ M, respectively.
Compounds (±)- 1 and (±)- 2 were also synthesized in this report.

The fern Drynaria roosii Nakaike ( Polypodiaceae ) is widely distributed in South China . Its rhizomes are used as the traditional Chinese medicine Gu-Sui-Bu for treatment of osteoporosis and bone fractures ( ). Previous studies indicated that the main components in D. roosii are flavonoids, phenylpropanoids, lignans and triterpenes ( ; , , , ; , , 2010). Among them, phenylpropanoids and lignans exhibited various biological activities, including anti-inflammatory ( ; ; ), cytotoxic ( ; ) and antioxidant ( ; ) activities, etc. Therefore, we conducted a study on the chemical constituents of D. roosii to search for more bioactive phenylpropanoids and lignans. Herein, we describe the isolation, structure elucidation and cytotoxic activity of five undescribed bis(lauric acid-12-yl)lignanoates that we named as liglaurates A–E ( 1–5 ) ( Fig. 1 ), together with the known methyl 12-caffeoyloxylaurate ( 6 ) ( ) and glyceryl 12-caffeoyloxylaurate ( 7 ) ( ).

sec.title: 2.1. Isolation and structure elucidation
sec.p: Liglaurate A ( 1 ) was purified as a brown oil. The molecular formula of C 44 H 62 O 12 was established by HRESIMS at m / z 805.4129 [M +Na] + (calcd. for C 44 H 62 O 12 Na, 805.4133) with 14 degrees of unsaturation ( Fig. S1 ). The IR spectrum showed absorption for hydroxyl (3388 cm-1 ) and aromatic (1652, 1521 cm 1 ) functionalities. The 1 H NMR signals ( Table 1 ) at δ H (7.50, 6.76, 6.64, 6.56, 6.47, 6.41,4.39 and 3.91) and the 13 C NMR signals at δ c (173.8, 167.7, 146.6, 143.8, 143.4, 142.9, 138.3, 135.2, 130.4, 124.1, 122.3, 119.9, 116.1, 116.0, 115.3, 114.9, 47.7, 45.6) ( Table 2 ), as well as the UV spectrum at λ max ( 343, 314, 294, 252 nm ) indicated that compound 1 was extremely analogous to those of known lignan, 6,7-dihydroxy-1-(3 ′ ,4 ′ -dihydroxyphenyl)-1,2-dihydronaphthalene-2,3-dicarboxylic acid ( ) that was renamed trivially as epiphyllic acid ( ). The

* Corresponding author. State Key Laboratory of Functions and Applications of Medicinal Plants, Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, 550014, China . ** Corresponding author. State Key Laboratory of Functions and Applications of Medicinal Plants, Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, 550014, China . E-mail addresses: weimingzhu@ouc.edu.cn (W. Zhu), lipingw2006@163.com (L. Wang). 1 These authors contributed equally.

skeleton was further confirmed by the key HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from H-7 ( δ H 7.50) to C-9 ( δ C 167.7)/C-2 ( δ C 130.4)/C-6 ( δ C 116.1)/C-8 ′ ( δ C 47.7), from H-3 ( δ H 6.56) to C-5 ( δ C 143.4)/C-1 ( δ C 124.1)/C-7 ′ ( δ C 45.6), from H-6 ( δ H 6.76) to C-4 ( δ C 146.6)/C-2, from H-2 ′ ( δ H 6.47) to C-4 ′ ( δ C 142.9)/C-6 ′ ( δ C 119.9), from H-5 ′ ( δ H 6.64) to C-1 ′ ( δ C 135.2)/C-3 ′ ( δ C 143.8), from H-6 ′ ( δ H 6.41) to C-4 ′ /C-7 ′ , from H-7 ′ ( δ H 4.39) to C-8 ( δ C 122.3), and from H-8 ′ ( δ H 3.91) to C-9 ′ ( δ C 173.8)/C-2, along with the COSY correlation between H-7 ′ and H-8 ′ . Except for the signals corresponding to lignan structure, the other NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) showed high similarities to the methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate, which was also present in the reported compound 6 ( Fig. 1 , Table S1 ). Two methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate moieties and the lignan skeleton were connected by a diester group between 9,9 ′ -dicarboxylic acid and 12-hydroxyl, based on the key HMBC correlations from H-1 ′′ ( δ H 4.10) to C-9 and H-1 ′′′ ( δ H 3.98) to C-9 ′ ( Fig. 2 ). To further verify the structure, the tetra- O -methyl derivatives 1a was prepared by methylation with iodomethane. Compound 1a was then treated with sodium hydroxide to give 4,5,3 ′ ,4 ′ -tetra- O -methylepiphyllic acid ( 1b ) and 12-hydroxyllauric acid ( 1c ) ( Fig. 5 ). The products 1a and 1b were identified by HRESIMS, 1 H and 13 C NMR data, while 1c was characterized by HRESIMS at m/z 215.16484 [M–H] – (calcd. for C 12 H 23 O 3 , 215.16417) (Fig. S53). The planar structure of 1 was thus established as shown in Fig. 1 .

The coupling constant ( J = 2.4 Hz) between H-7 ′ and H-8 ′ was in accordance with trans -configuration ( ). Moreover, the NOESY correlation between H-8 ′ and H-2 ′ ( Fig. 3 ) further indicated the trans -orientation between H-7 ′ and H-8 ′ ( Fig. 2 ). In addition, compound 1 was found to be a racemate according to the zero optical rotation and no ECD Cotton effect. It was then separated by semi-preparative HPLC on Cellulose-5 chiral column to afford the optically pure enantiomers, (+)- 1 and ()- 1 (Fig. S58). The absolute configurations of (+)- 1 and ()- 1 were determined by ECD calculation using the time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level ( Fig. 4 ). Considering the high conformational flexibility of 1 , the ECD calculation may impose high uncertainty. Compound 1b was therefore selected for further analysis. Similarly, compound 1b was found to be a racemate, which was also separated as the optically pure enantiomers, (+)- 1b and ()- 1b , by semi-preparative HPLC on Cellulose-5 chiral column (Fig. S58). The ECD calculation indicated that the absolute configurations of (+)- 1b and ()- 1b were (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )-, respectively. Besides, similar Cotton effect of (+)- 1 with (+)- 1b , and ()- 1 with ()- 1b was observed ( Fig. 4 ), indicating that the fatty acid part has little effects on determination of the absolute configuration. Thus, the absolute configuration of (+)- 1 and ()- 1 were assigned as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )-, respectively.

To further verify the structure, compound (±)- 1 was synthesized from caffeic acid and 12-hydroxyllauric acid ( Fig. 6 ). Methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate was first synthesized from 12-hydroxyllauric acid in the condition of methanol and sulfuric acid. Then methyl 12-caffeoyloxylaurate ( 6 ) was synthesized from caffeic acid and methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate using Mitsunobu reaction. Finally, compound (±)- 1 was synthesized by a metal-mediated oxidative coupling reaction from compound 6 ( ), which was further resolved as (+)- 1 and ()- 1 as well (Fig. S58). Therefore, the structures of (+)- 1 and ()- 1 were respectively identified as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )- di (12-methoxy-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) epiphyllate.

Liglaurate B ( 2 ) was isolated as a brown oil with the formula of C 48 H 70 O 16 from HRESIMS at m/z 925.4548[M + Na] + (calcd. for C 48 H 70 O 16 Na, 925.4556). The NMR spectroscopic data of compound 2 was very similar to those of 1 , only differed in the substituents at C-12’’/ 12 ′′′ . The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-15’’/15 ′′′ ( δ H 3.35–3.33) and H-14’’/14 ′′′ ( δ H 3.64–3.61) through H-13’’/13 ′′′ ( δ H 4.03–4.01, 3.89–3.87), as well as the key HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from H-13’’/13 ′′′ and H-10’’/10 ′′′ ( δ H 1.53–1.49) to C-12’’/12 ′′′ ( δ C 173.0), H-1 ′′ ( δ H 4.04) to C-9 ( δ C 166.2), and H-1 ′′′ ( δ H 3.91) to C-9 ′ ( δ C 171.9) indicated that the glyceryl groups in 2 replaced the methoxy groups in 1 . This was evidenced from the synthesis of 2 by a metal-mediated oxidative coupling reaction from compound 7 ( Fig. 7 ). Compound 2 was also a racemate, which was further separated as the optically pure (+)- 2 and ()- 2 on Cellulose-5 chiral column (Fig. S58). The same (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- configuration for (+)- 2 and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )- for ()- 2 were assigned according to the similar ECD spectra of (+)- 2 with (+)- 1 and ()- 2 with ()- 1 ( Fig. 4 ). Thus, structures (+)- 2 and ()- 2 were respectively identified as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )- di(12-glyceryl-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) epiphyllate.

The molecular formula of liglaurate C ( 3 ) was determined to be C 46 H 66 O 14 on the basis of HRESIMS peak at m / z 865.4351 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 46 H 66 O 14 Na, 865.4345). Its NMR spectroscopic data suggested a structural resemblance to 1 , with the only difference being the presence of a glyceryl signal in 3 instead of a methoxy signal in 1 ( Tables 1 and 2 ), which was confirmed by key HMBC correlations (Fig. S22) from H-13’’/13 ′′′ ( δ H 4.03–4.01, 3.91–3.89, 3.57) to C-12’’/12 ′′′ ( δ C 173.4, 173.0). This implied that compound 3 is a mix ester containing methyl and glyceryl groups. To further verify the 12-hydroxyllaurate and lignan skeleton, the tetra- O -methyl derivative was prepared and then treated with sodium hydroxide to give 1b and 1c using the same method as compound 1 ( Fig. 5 and S55). After subjected to HPLC separation on Cellulose-5 chiral column, (±)- 3 was also resolved as the enantiomeric (+)- 3 and ()- 3 (Fig. S58). The configurations of (+)- 3 and ()- 3 were assigned as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )-, respectively, by the ECD consistency with (+)- 1 and ()- 1 ( Fig. 4 ). However, the location of glycerol or methoxy group on C-12 ′′ or C-12 ′′′ could not be determined for the overlap of the two laurates signals around the carboxylate. Thus, structures (+)- 3 and ()- 3 were respectively assigned as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )- (12-glyceryl-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) (12- methoxy-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) epiphyllate.

Liglaurate D ( 4 ) was isolated as a brown oil with the molecular formula of C 45 H 64 O 14 from the HRESIMS peak at m / z 851.4182 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 45 H 64 O 14 Na, 851.4188). The NMR spectroscopic data suggested a structural similarity with compound 2 , and the difference being only one glyceryl ester bonded to the 12-hydroxyllauric acid ( Tables 1 and 2 ). Using the same method as compound 1 , the methyl derivative was prepared and then treated with sodium hydroxide to give 1b and 1c ( Fig. 5 and S56) to confirm the 12-hydroxyllaurate and lignan skeleton. Like compounds 1–3 , compound 4 was also a racemic mixture and resolved as the enantiomeric (+)- 4 and ()- 4 by a semi-preparative HPLC on Cellulose-5 chiral column (Fig. S58). The configurations of (+)- 4 and ()- 4 were assigned as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )-, respectively, by the ECD consistency with (+)- 1 and ()- 1 ( Fig. 4 ). However, the location of glycerol on C-12 ′′ or C-12 ′′′ could not be determined for the overlap of the two laurates signals around the carboxylate. Thus, the structures of (+)- 4 and ()- 4 were respectively assigned as (7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- and (7 ′ R , 8 ′ S )- (12-glyceryl-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) (12-hydroxy-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) epiphyllate.

Liglaurate E ( 5 ) was isolated as a yellow oil with the molecular formula of C 44 H 58 O 12 by a HRESIMS peak at m / z 801.3824 [M +Na] + (calcd. for C 44 H 58 O 12 Na, 801.3820). The 1 H NMR signals ( Table 1 ) at δ H (8.04, 7.49, 7.29, 6.96 and 6.62) and the 13 C NMR signals ( Table 2 ) at δ c (169.7, 165.8, 148.7, 146.1, 142.0 × 2, 136.5, 128.1, 125.9, 124.7, 124.1, 122.9, 121.2, 120.0, 119.8, 111.2, 108.8, 103.8) were close to arylnaphthalenoid lignan, mongolicumin A ( ). This deduction was supported from the key HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of H-6 ( δ H 7.49) to C-4 ( δ C 142.0)/C-7 ( δ C 128.1)/C-2 ( δ C 122.9), of H-5 ( δ H 7.29) to C-3 ( δ C 136.5)/C-1 ( δ C 125.9), of H-7 ( δ H 8.04) to C-9 ( δ C 165.8)/C-2/C-8 ′ ( δ C 119.8), of H-6 ′ ( δ H 6.96) to C-4 ′ ( δ C 148.7)/C-2 ′ ( δ C 142.0)/C-7 ′ ( δ C 124.1), and H-3 ′ ( δ H 6.62) to C-5 ′ ( δ C 146.1)/C-1 ′ ( δ C 108.8), along with the COSY correlation between H-5 and H-6. Except for the signals of mongolicumin A moiety, the other NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) showed high similarities to the methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate unit that was also presented in compounds 1 and 6 ( Fig. 1 , Table S1 ). Two methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate moieties and the mongolicumin A moiety were connected by two ester bonds between 9,9 ′ -dicarboxylic acid and 12-hydroxyl, which was evidenced by the key HMBC correlations from H-1 ′′ ( δ H 4.20) to C-9 and H-1 ′′′ ( δ H 4.33) to C-9 ′ ( δ C 169.7) ( Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, by the same procedure as compound 1 , the methylation of compound 5 followed by basic hydrolysis also provided 4,4 ′ ,5 ′ -tri-- O -methyl mongolicumin A and 12-hydroxyllauric acid ( 1c ) from the HPLC-HRESIMS analysis (Fig. S57). Thus, the structure of compound 5 was concluded to be 9,9 ′ -di- O -(12-methoxy-12-oxydodecan-1-yl) mongolicumin A.

Two known compounds, methyl 12-caffeoyloxylaurate ( 6 ) ( ) and glyceryl 12-caffeoyloxylaurate ( 7 ) ( ) were identified by comparison of their NMR data ( Table S1 ) with those reported in the literature.

sec.title: 2.2. Anti-inflammatory activity
sec.p: As showed in Table 3 , compounds 1–4 and 7 showed toxicity against RAW264.7 cell line with the inhibition rate greater than 50% at 10.0 μ M, but compounds 5 and 6 showed weak toxicity at 10.0 μ M. Compounds 5 and 6 showed notable inhibitory effects on the lipopolysaccharides (LPS) induced nitric oxide (NO) production in murine macrophage cell line, RAW264.7 ( Table 4 ).

sec.title: 2.3. Cytotoxic activity
sec.p: Compounds 1–4 were evaluated cytotoxicity against HeLa, HCT-116, MCF-7, HepG2, MV4-11 and HEK293T cell lines. The results ( Table 5 ) showed that compounds 1–4 exhibited the remarkable cytotoxic activities especially for HeLa cell line, with the IC 50 values of 0.16 ± 0.02, 0.06 ±0.01, 0.34 ±0.07 and 0.17 ±0.01 μ M, respectively, more active than adriamycin (IC 50 1.49 ±0.26 μ M). Interestingly, the optically pure compounds (+)- 1 and (+)- 2 showed stronger activity than their enantiomers against the HeLa cell line proliferation ( Table 5 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Measured in CDCl.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 3 b Measured in DMSO‑ d .

sec.title: 2.4. Anti-oxidant activity
sec.p: Compounds 1–7 were also evaluated their antioxidant activity by DPPH and ORAC assays. As expected, compounds 1–7 exhibited significant DPPH radical-scavenging activity than vitamin C (VC) with the IC 50 values of 3.04 ±0.11, 1.94 ±0.03, 4.23 ±0.12, 2.24 ±0.08, 4.98 ± 0.06, 8.49 ± 0.26, 6.95 ± 0.20 μ M and 12.67 ± 0.31 μ M (VC), respectively ( Table 6 ). In addition, compound (±)- 4 showed a remarkable antioxidative capacity with an ORAC value of 1.05 ±0.07 μ mol TE/ μ mol ( Table 6 ).

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, apart from two known 12-caffeoyloxylaurates ( 6 and 7 ), five undescribed bis(lauric acid-12-yl)lignan esters ( 1–5 ) were isolated and identified from the rhizomes of D. roosii . Compounds 1–4 were isolated as the racemic mixtures and further resolved into the enantiomerically pure compounds by a chiral purification. Compounds 1–4 were postulated biosynthesis from the [4 +2] cycloaddition reaction of two caffeates between Δ 6,8 (diene) and Δ 7,8 (ene) while compound 5 is from the [4 + 2] cycloaddition reaction between Δ 2,8 (diene) and Δ 7,8 (ene) of the caffeates followed by oxidative dehydrogenation and intramolecular etherification ( Fig. 8 ). Among them, compounds (±)- 1 and (±)- 2 were synthesized by a metal-mediated oxidative coupling reaction. Compounds (±)- 1 –(±)- 4 and the optically pure (+)- 1 , (+)- 2 , ()- 1 and ()- 2 showed a selective cytotoxicity against HeLa cell line, indicating their potential use in the discovery of drugs for fighting human cervix cancer.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations were determined on a JASCOP-1020 digital polarimeter. UV spectra were measured on a Waters 2487 dual λ absorbance detector. ECD spectra were collected using a JASCO J-715 spectropolarimeter. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Nexus 470 spectrophotometer as KBr disks. 1 H, 13 C NMR and 2D NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker-600 MHz using TMS as an internal standard. ESIMS and HRESIMS analysis was carried out on Waters Xevo TQS and Agilent Technologies 6530 Accurate-Mass QTOF LC/MS, respectively. Column chromatography was performed on silica gel (200–300 mesh; Qingdao Puke Parting Materials Co., Ltd., China ), Sephadex LH-20 (Amersham Biosciences, Uppsala , Sweden ), and plates precoated with silica gel GF254 (Qingdao Puke Parting Materials Co., Ltd., China ), respectively. HPLC separation was performed on HITACHI Primaide with an ODS column (YMC-pack ODS-A, 10 mm × 250 mm , 5 μ m, 4 mL/min) and a πNAP column (COSMUSIL, 10 mm × 250 mm , 5 μ m, 4 mL/min). Chiral separation was performed using chiral column (Cellulose-5, 250 × 4.6 mm , Phenomenex, USA ). Some fractions were purified using a SepaBean machine equipped with SepaFlash columns (Santai Technologies Inc., China ).

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p: The rhizomes of Drynaria roosii Nakaike ( Polypodiaceae ) were collected from Dushan, (GPS coordinates: 25 ◦ 04 ′ – 26 ◦ 31 ′ N , 107 ◦ 41 ′ 107 ◦ 55 ′ E ), Guizhou Province of China , in May 2019 of dry season, and were authenticated by Dr. Wei Gu. A voucher specimen (H20190522) has been deposited at the Key Laboratory of Chemistry for Natural Products of Guizhou Province and Chinese Academy of Sciences .

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Measured in CDCl. 3 b Measured in DMSO‑ d .

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: The dried rhizomes of plant material ( 50 kg ) were ground into powder, and then extracted four times with methanol (MeOH) at room temperature to afford a crude extract ( 5.2 kg ). The extract was washed with petroleum ether (PE) to afford 3.9 kg of crude. The crude was diluted with water and extracted with PE: EtOAc (v/v, 1:1) to obtain 68.4 g of extract, which was separated with silica gel chromatography eluted by a gradient mixture of PE-EtOAc (v/v 100:0 to 50:1), CH 2 Cl 2 - EtOAc (v/v 50:1 to 10:1) and CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v 20:1, 10:1 and 2:1) to yield 22 fractions (Fr.1~Fr.22). Fraction 18 ( 1.8 g ) was further purified on a Sephadex LH-20 column washed with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v, 1:1) to obtain nine subfractions (Fr.18–1~Fr.18–9). Fr.18–4 ( 153.7 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O containing 0.15% TFA, 88:12, v/v, 4 mL/min) to yield racemic 1 ( 13.3 mg , t R 13.2 min). The racemic 1 was further separated on Cellulose-5 chiral column (MeOH/H 2 O, 90:10, v/v, 0.8 mL/min) to give the optically-pure (+)- 1 ( 1.1 mg , t R 16.1 min) and ()- 1 (1.0 mg, t R 18.7 min). Fraction 22 ( 1.2 g ) was further separated into six subfractions (Fr.22–1~Fr.22–6) by Sephadex LH-20 eluting with MeOH– CH 2 Cl 2 (v/ v, 1:1), and then Fr.22–5 (435.0 mg) was purified by SepaBean machine eluting with 5–100% MeOH/H 2 O to provide racemic 2 ( 16.2 mg ). The racemic 2 was further separated on Cellulose-5 chiral column (MeOH/ H 2 O, 80:20, v/v, 0.8 mL/min) to give the optically-pure (+)- 2 ( 1.2 mg , t R 19.0 min) and ()- 2 (1.0 mg, t R 22.8 min). Fr.22–3 ( 259.1 mg ) was purified by SepaBean machine eluting with 5–100% MeOH/H 2 O to provide five subfractions (Fr.22-3-1~Fr.22-3-5). Fr.22-3-5 ( 18.8 mg ) was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC on a πNAP column (MeOH/H 2 O, 86:14, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give racemic 3 ( 11.3 mg , t R 11.6 min). The racemic 3 was further separated on Cellulose-5 chiral column (MeOH/H 2 O, 85:15, v/v, 0.8 mL/min) to give the optically-pure (+)- 3 ( 1.1 mg , t R 18.2 min) and ()- 3 (1.0 mg, t R 21.6 min). By the same procedure, Fr.22-3-2 ( 9.6 mg ) was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC on a πNAP column (MeOH/H 2 O, 85:15, v/v, 4 mL/min) to yield racemic 4 ( 3.2 mg , t R 10.2 min). The racemic 4 was further separated on Cellulose-5 chiral column (MeOH/H 2 O, 80:20, v/v, 0.8 mL/min) to give the optically-pure (+)- 4 ( 1.2 mg , t R 15.2 min) and ()- 4 (1.0 mg, t R 18.0 min). Fraction 16 ( 1.7 g ) was further purified on a Sephadex LH-20 column washed with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v, 1:1) to afford eleven subfractions (Fr.16–1~Fr.16–11), Fr.16–4 ( 171.5 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 93:7, v/v, 4 mL/min) to yield compound 5 (16.0 mg, t R 12.0 min). Fraction 8 ( 879.5 mg ) was further purified on a Sephadex LH-20 column washed with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v, 1:1) to afford seven subfractions (Fr.8–1~Fr.8–7). Fr.8–4 ( 90.8 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O containing 0.15% TFA, 80:20, v/v, 4 mL/min) to yield compound 6 ( 9.1 mg , t R 13.4 min). Fraction 20 ( 826.7 mg ) was further purified on a Sephadex LH-20 column washed down with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v, 1:1) to separate into nine subfractions (Fr.20–1~Fr.20–9), Fr-20-6 ( 167.9 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O containing 0.15% TFA, 73:27, v/v, 4 mL/min) to yield compound 7 ( 39.3 mg , t R 11.6 min).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a IC values were obtained from three independent experiments and repre- 50 sented as the mean ± SD.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b HeLa, human cervix adenocarcinoma cell line.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: c HCT-116, human colon carcinoma cell line.

sec.title: 4.4.1. Synthesis of compound ( ± )-1
sec.p: d MCF-7, human breast adenocarcinoma cell line.

Synthesis of methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate: To a solution of 12-hydroxyllauric acid (1.0 g, 4.6 mmol) in methanol (40 mL) was slowly added concentrated H 2 SO 4 (200 μ L, 18.4 M ) and refluxed for 4 h. Then the reaction cooled to room temperature and the methanol was then concentrated in vacuo . The mixture was diluted with EtOAc (20 mL) and was rinsed with brine, dried over Na 2 SO 4 , and concentrated in vacuo .
e HepG2, human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line.
f MV4-11, human myelomonocytic leukemia cell line.
g HEK293T, human embryonic kidney cell line.
h Adriamycin (Adr.) was used as positive control.

The crude was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O containing 0.15% TFA, 70:30, v/v, 4 mL/min) to provide methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate as a white oil ( 0.871 g , 82% yield, t R 18.2 min): 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) δ 3.62 (s, 3H), 3.58 (t, J =6.7 Hz, 2H), 2.26 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.58–1.55 (m, 2H), 1.53–1.50 (m, 2H), 1.31–1.29 (m, 2H), 1.26–1.20 (m, 12H). 13 C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl 3 ) δ 174.5, 62.9, 51.5, 34.2, 32.8, 29.6, 29.5 × 3, 29.3, 29.2, 25.8, 25.0; ESIMS m/z 253.2 [M+Na] + .

Synthesis of compound 6 : methyl 12-hydroxyllaurate ( 575 mg , 2.5 mmol), caffeic acid ( 0.9 g , 5.0 mmol), and triphenylphosphine (PPh 3 ) ( 1.965 g , 7.5 mmol) were dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (60 mL), and the mixture was stirred at 0 ◦ C for 5 min. Then diethyl azodiacetate (DEAD) (1.825 mL, 7.5 mmol) was added dropwise to the reaction, and stirred at 25 ◦ C under an argon atmosphere for 9 h. The reaction mixture was quenched with water (20 mL), extracted with EtOAc (100 mL) and the combined organic phase was dried over Na 2 SO 4 . After removal of the solvent in vacuo , the residue was purified by SepaBean machine eluting with 5–100% MeOH/H 2 O to afford the crude residue. The crude residue was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 83:17, v/v, 4 mL/min) to afford compound 6 as a yellow oil ( 389.1 mg , 40% yield, t R 13.2 min): ESIMS m/z 415.4 [M+Na] + ; NMR data was listed in Table S1 .

Synthesis of compound (±)- 1 : To a solution of 6 ( 300 mg , 0.77 mmol) in acetone (15 mL), a solution of FeCl 3 ⋅6H 2 O ( 1.8 g , 6.67 mmol) in H 2 O (1.5 mL) was added below 5 ◦ C over 1.5 h and the mixture was kept at 0 ◦ C overnight. The acetone was evaporated off in vacuo , then the mixture was diluted with EtOAc (20 mL) and rinsed with brine, dried over Na 2 SO 4 , and concentrated in vacuo . The residue was purified on a Sephadex LH-20 column eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v, 1:1) to afford the crude residue. The crude residue was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O containing 0.15% TFA, 85:15, v/v, 4 mL/min) to afford compound (±)- 1 as a brown oil ( 29.6 mg , 10% yield, t R 17.8 min): HRESIMS m / z 805.41284 [M +Na] + (calcd. for C 44 H 62 O 12 Na, 805.41335); NMR data see Tables 1 and 2

sec.title: 4.4.2. Synthesis of compound ( ± )-2
sec.p: To a solution of 7 ( 20 mg , 0.04 mmol) in acetone (1.5 mL), FeCl 3 ⋅6H 2 O ( 120 mg , 0.44 mmol) in H 2 O (100 μL) was added below 5 ◦ C over 1.5 h and the mixture was kept at 0 ◦ C overnight. The acetone was evaporated off in vacuo , then the mixture was diluted with EtOAc (10 mL) and rinsed with brine, dried over Na 2 SO 4 , and concentrated in vacuo . The residue was purified on a Sephadex LH-20 column eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (v/v, 1:1) to afford the crude residue. The crude residue was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeCN/H 2 O, 55:45, v/v, 4 mL/min) to afford the desired compound (±)- 2 as a brown oil ( 1.8 mg , 10% yield, t R 16.2 min): HRESIMS m / z 925.45306 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 48 H 70 O 16 Na, 925.45561); NMR data see Tables 1 and 2

sec.title: 4.4.3. Methylation of 1
sec.p: To a solution of compound 1 (16.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) and K 2 CO 3 ( 330 mg , 2.4 mmol) in dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) was added CH 3 I (96 μ L, 1.5 mmol) and stirred at 80 ◦ C for 9 h. The reaction was quenched by adding 5 mL of saturated NH 4 Cl and diluted with EtOAc (10 mL). The resulting EtOAc solution was washed with H 2 O (10 mL) and brine (10 mL) in order, dried over Na 2 SO 4 , filtered, and concentrated in vacuo . The crude product was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 94:6, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give 1a as a yellow oil (11.0 mg, 0.013 mmol, 65% yield, t R 12.0 min). 1 H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl 3 ) δ 7.62 (s, 1H, H-7), 6.86 (s, 1H, H-6), 6.68 (d, J =8.4 Hz, 1H, H-5 ′ ), 6.64 (s, 1H, H-3), 6.63 (s, 1H, H-2 ′ ), 6.45 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.8 Hz, 1H, H-6 ′ ), 4.73 (s, 1H, H-7 ′ ), 4.62 (d, J =3.0 Hz, 1H, H-8 ′ ), 4.12 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, H-1 ′′ ), 4.00–3.98 (m, 2H, H-1 ′′′ ), 3.91/3.81/ 3.80/3.78 (s, 3H each, 4/5/3’/4 ′ -OCH 3 ), 3.66 (s, 6H, 13’’/13 ′′′ -OCH 3 ), 2.29 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, H-11’’/11 ′′′ ), 1.66–1.64 (m, 2H, H-2 ′′ ), 1.62–1.59 (m, 4H, H-10’’/10 ′′′ ), 1.50–1.47 (m, 2H, H-2 ′′′ ), 1.35–1.32 (m,

sec.title: 4.4.4. Methylation of 2–5
sec.p: To a solution of compound 2 (8.0 mg, 0.009 mmol) and K 2 CO 3 (165.0 mg, 1.2 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) was added a solution of CH 3 I (48 μ L, 0.8 mmol) and stirred at 80 ◦ C for 9 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted by the same procedure as methylation of compound 1 . The crude product was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 85:15, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give 2a ( 2.6 mg , 0.003 mmol, 33%, t R 10.6 min) as a yellow oil: ESIMS m/z 981.3 [M+Na] + .

To a solution of compound 3 (10.0 mg, 0.012 mmol) and K 2 CO 3 ( 206 mg , 1.5 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) was added a solution of CH 3 I (60 μ L, 1.0 mmol) and stirred at 80 ◦ C for 9 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted by the same procedure as methylation of compound 1 . The crude product was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 88:12, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give 3a (3.0 mg, 0.003 mmol, 25%, t R 13.8 min) as a yellow oil: ESIMS m/z 921.5 [M+Na] + .

To a solution of compound 4 ( 8.9 mg , 0.011 mmol) and K 2 CO 3 ( 206 mg , 1.5 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) was added a solution of CH 3 I (60 μ L, 1.0 mmol) and stirred at 80 ◦ C for 9 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted by the same procedure as methylation of compound 1 . The crude product was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 88:12, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give 4a ( 2.7 mg , 0.003 mmol, 27%, t R 13.8 min) as a yellow oil: ESIMS m/z 921.5 [M+Na] + .

To a solution of compound 5 (9.0 mg, 0.012 mmol) and K 2 CO 3 ( 206 mg , 1.5 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) was added a solution of CH 3 I (60.0 μ L, 1.0 mmol) and stirred at 80 ◦ C for 9 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted by the same procedure as methylation of compound 1 . The crude product was purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 95:5, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give 5a ( 2.9 mg , 0.004 mmol, 33%, t R 15.4 min) as a yellow oil: ESIMS m/z 843.3 [M+Na] + .

sec.title: 4.4.5. Hydrolysis of 1a
sec.p: To a solution of 1a (8.0 mg, 0.01 mmol) in ethanol (1 mL) was added aqueous NaOH solution (20 μ L, 2.25 M ) and refluxed for 5 h. Then the reaction cooled to room temperature and was adjusted to pH 3.0 with 0.1 M hydrochloric acid, and the ethanol was then evaporated off in vacuo . The mixture was diluted with H 2 O (10 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (20 mL) and the organic layer was rinsed with brine, dried over Na 2 SO 4 , and concentrated in vacuo . The crude product was analyzed by HPLC-HRESIMS, which showed two main peaks at m/z 413.12442 [MH] - (calcd. for C 22 H 21 O 8 , 413.12309) and m/z 215.16484 [M–H] – (calcd. for C 12 H 23 O 3 , 215.16417) respectively (Fig. S53), corresponding to the desired products 1b and 1c . The mixture was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC on an ODS column (MeOH/H 2 O, 45:55, v/v, 4 mL/min) to give 1b as a yellow oil ( 3.4 mg , 0.008 mmol, 80% yield, t R 10.2 min). The racemic 1b was further separated on Cellulose-5 chiral column eluting with MeOH/H 2 O containing 0.05% TFA (55:45, v/v, 0.8 mL/min) to give the optically-pure (+)- 1b ( 1.1 mg , t R 19.4 min) and ()- 1b (1.0 mg, t R 26.8 min). 1 H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl 3 ) δ 7.77 (s, 1H, H-7), 6.88 (s, 1H, H-6), 6.66 (s, 1H, H-3), 6.65 (d, J =8.2 Hz, 1H, H-5 ′ ), 6.57 (s, 1H, H-2 ′ ), 6.37 (d, J =8.2 Hz, 1H, H-6 ′ ), 4.64 (s, 1H, H-7 ′ ), 3.93 (s, 1H, H-8 ′ ), 3.90/3.83/3.78/3.76 (s, 3H each, 4/5/3’/4 ′ -OCH 3 ); 13 C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl 3 ) δ 178.5 (C-9 ′ ), 172.4 (C-9), 151.6 (C-4), 149.1 (C-3 ′ ), 148.5 (C-5), 148.2 (C-4 ′ ), 140.2 (C-7), 135.0 (C-1 ′ ), 130.5 (C-2), 124.1 (C-1), 121.2 (C-8), 119.6 (C-6 ′ ), 112.3 (C-6), 112.2 (C-3), 111.3

sec.title: 4.4.6. Hydrolysis of 2a-5a
sec.p: To a solution of 2a ( 2.6 mg , 0.003 mmol) in ethanol (1 mL) was added aqueous NaOH solution (20 μ L, 2.25 M ) and refluxed for 5 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted under the same conditions as hydrolysis of 1a , then obtained two main peaks at m/z 413.12286 [MH] - (calcd. for C 22 H 21 O 8 , 413.12309) and m/z 215.16408 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 12 H 23 O 3 , 215.16417) in the HPLC-HRESIMS (Fig. S54), corresponding to the desired products 1b and 1c .

To a solution of 3a (3.0 mg, 0.003 mmol) in ethanol (1 mL) was added aqueous NaOH solution (20 μ L, 2.25 M ) and refluxed for 5 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted under the same conditions as hydrolysis of 1a , then obtained two main peaks at m/z 413.12421 [MH] - (calcd. for C 22 H 21 O 8 , 413.12309) and m/z 215.16476 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 12 H 23 O 3 , 215.16417) in the HPLC-HRESIMS (Fig. S55), corresponding to the desired products 1b and 1c .

To a solution of 4a ( 1.7 mg , 0.002 mmol) in ethanol (1 mL) was added aqueous NaOH solution (20 μ L, 2.25 M ) and refluxed for 5 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted under the same conditions as hydrolysis of 1a , then obtained two main peaks at m/z 413.12326 [MH] - (calcd. for C 22 H 21 O 8 , 413.12309) and m/z 215.16415 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 12 H 23 O 3 , 215.16417) in the HPLC-HRESIMS (Fig. S56), corresponding to the desired products 1b and 1c .

To a solution of 5a ( 2.9 mg , 0.004 mmol) in ethanol (1 mL) was added aqueous NaOH solution (20 μ L, 2.25 M ) and refluxed for 5 h. Then the reaction was quenched and extracted under the same conditions as hydrolysis of 1a , then obtained two main peaks at m/z 395.07703 [MH] - (calcd. for C 21 H 15 O 8 , 395.07614) and m/z 215.16458 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 12 H 23 O 3 , 215.16417) in the HPLC-HRESIMS (Fig. S57), corresponding to the desired products 5b and 1c .

sec.title: 4.5.5. Liglaurate E (5)
sec.p: Yellow oil; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ): 393 (4.23), 268 (4.58) nm; IR (KBr) v max 3428, 2923, 2852, 2358, 1716, 1631, 1521, 1455, 1265, 1197 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, ( Tables 1 and 2 ); HRESIMS m / z 801.3824 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 44 H 58 O 12 Na, 801.3820).

sec.title: 4.6. Theoretical ECD calculation
sec.p: Theoretical calculations of ECD spectra for compounds 1–4 were performed with Gaussian 09 ( ; ). The preliminary conformational distributions search was carried out by SYBYL-X 2.0 software. The ground-state geometries were optimized at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level. The ECD of the selected conformers with distributions higher than 1% were then calculated by the TD-DFT method at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level with the PCM model in methanol solution. The calculated ECD spectra were produced by SpecDis 1.70.1 ( ).

sec.title: 4.7. In vitro cytotoxic assay
sec.p: Cell proliferation was measured by Cell Counting Kit-8 (CCK-8, Solarbio life sciences) method ( ). Cell suspension of 100 μ L was dispensed (5 × 104 cells/well) in 96-well plates. The plates were pre-incubated for 24 h, followed by the treatments of either DMSO (control) or various concentrations of compounds 1–7 with 10 μ M for RAW264.7 cell line, compounds 1–4 and positive control adriamycin with different concentrations (from 10 μ M to 0.001 μ M) for HeLa, HCT-116, MCF-7, HepG2, MV4-11 and HEK293T cell lines. The 96-well plates were placed at 37 ◦ C and cultured in a 5% CO 2 incubator for 72 h. Aspirated the old medium, and directly added the 10-fold diluted CCK-8 (100 μ L) solution to each well of the plate and incubated the plate for 3 h in the incubator. The absorbance was measured at 450 nm using an absorbance microplate reader (Thermo Scientific MULTISKAN MK3). The optical density values of each well represented the survival/proliferation of cells. The half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50 ) is defined as the concentration within 50% inhibition.

sec.title: 4.8. In vitro anti-inflammatory assay
sec.p: The anti-inflammatory activity was tested by NO inhibition on RAW264.7 cell line using Griess assay ( ). The murine macrophage cell line RAW264.7 was cultured in Dulbecco’ s modified Eagle’ s medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and incubated at 37 ◦ C in a 5% CO 2 atmosphere with a 6 well plates. After 24 h, the condition medium was replaced with fresh DMEM and FBS. Then, compounds 5 and 6 (10.0 μ M, dexamethasone used as positive control) also with lipopolysaccharide (LPS, 100 ng /mL) were added, and incubated for 24 h. The cultured cells were then centrifuged, and the supernatants were used for NO-production measurement. The supernatant was mixed with an equal volume of the Griess Reagent (BEYOTIME Total Nitric Oxide Assay Kit) and incubated for 10 min at room temperature. The absorbance of each well was measured at 540
nm on a microplate reader (Thermo Scientific MULTISKAN MK3).

sec.title: 4.9.1. 2,2-Diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) radical-scavenging assay
sec.p: The DPPH radical-scavenging assay was carried out as described previously ( ).

sec.title: 4.9.2. Oxygen radical absorbance capacity (ORAC) assay
sec.p: The ORAC assay was carried out as described previously ( ).
